Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan in 1971 was a pivotal event in the history of South Asia. The country's struggle for self-determination was led by Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the founding father of Bangladesh. Rahman was a central figure in the Bangladeshi independence movement and served as the first President of the newly independent country. [Data: Entities (8, 20, 48); Relationships (9, 300)]

Prior to independence, Bangladesh was known as East Pakistan and faced longstanding political and cultural tensions with the Urdu-speaking West Pakistani elite. Tensions escalated after the 1970 general election, in which Rahman's Awami League party won a majority in the Pakistani parliament but was denied the right to form the government. This sparked widespread protests and a brutal crackdown by the Pakistani military, leading to the Bangladeshi Liberation War. 

The nine-month Liberation War was a bloody struggle, with the Bangladeshi Mukti Bahini forces engaging in guerrilla tactics against the Pakistani military. The war drew international condemnation and support for the Bangladeshi cause, with India providing crucial military and logistical assistance. After immense sacrifices, Bangladesh emerged as an independent nation on December 16, 1971. [Data: Relationships (94)]

Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's leadership and vision were instrumental in the country's independence. As the first President of Bangladesh, he worked to build the new nation's institutions and establish its place on the global stage. Rahman's pro-Soviet Union stance, however, contributed to tensions within the Bangladeshi military, which ultimately led to his assassination in 1975. [Data: Relationships (9, 300, 316)]
